text: (audience applauding)
Alright well first of all

I would like to thank
everyone at C&E News
for putting together this great event.
I'm very honored to be here.
So today I will share with you

a little bit about my
journey through the field
of supramolecular chemistry

but also some of the work
that my group is doing

in developing squaramide-based
supramolecular polymers
for applications in the biomedical area.
So, as I was preparing for my talk today,
I was sitting across from my daughter,

who was playing with one
of her most recent toys,
the Strawbees.

Strawbees are connector
pieces and drinking straws

that you can fit together
in order to build objects

with varied complexity,
but as well with function.
So, you can build, for example,

bridges that can sustain
more than their weight

and you can also build
objects that open and close
such as this umbrella shown here.
We can think of supramolecular chemistry
in an analogous way.

If, for example, we now
change out the drinking straws
and the connector pieces for molecules,

and we bring them together
using non-covalent interactions,

and we can bring them
together such that we can make
both discreet structures but as well,
polymeric architectures.

And what is common to these
two particular structures,

is that both of them can
show emergent properties

and functions when they
are self-assembled.
And so for example, if we're talking about

a particular polymer, the
polymer can show for example,

mechanical properties
or bioactive properties

that are not seen in
the individual monomers.

So, how did supramolecular
chemistry start out for me?

Supramolecular chemistry
started out for me

at the end of my undergrad,
at the University of Toronto,

and this is where I got
exposed as an inorganic chemist

to the field of
metallo-supramolecular chemistry,

and I was really attracted to
the high degree of symmetry

and as well, intricacy
of the various complexes.

But something as a synthetic
chemist that stuck with me

was that you could make these
very intricate structures
in very few synthetic steps.
So this led me to pursue looking for a PhD

in supramolecular
chemistry and this is how
I ended up at the group of Hanadi Sleiman
at McGill University in Canada,

and well, in her group
what I did was I developed
both monometallic platinum-based complexes
and as well supramolecular complexes

to target the guanine-quadruplex
as an anti-cancer strategy.

But what was really important
about this experience
was that I was able to interact with both
computational chemists and biologists

which very much stuck with me
in how I do research today.

But also I realized that
I really enjoyed working

at this interface of
chemistry and biology.
So, close to the end of my PhD,

I read a paper of Bert Meijer's
on supramolecular polymers

and I decided that I wanted
to change directions a bit

in my research, and so
this is what brought me
over to the Netherlands in his group,
at the Eindhoven University of Technology,

and it was in his group
that I was studying

or I was exploring, actually,
how we could bring these

supramolecular polymer
materials based on these

ureido-pyrimidinone units
into the biomedical area.
So I explored strategies to modulate
their mechanical properties by mixing

various monomer species or
supramolecular monomers,
and as well, looking at how to introduce

bio-activity through the
tethering of peptide moieties,
and it was after this stage that I became

only more curious in how far
we could push these materials

in order to really
instruct cellular behavior.
So this is what brought me towards

starting my independent
career at Leiden University,

and in my research group,
we are very interested
in how we can borrow ideas from nature

in how nature is able to
construct very complex structures,
starting from molecular building blocks
from the bottom up, and these structures

can also have function,
and in addition to this,
also how cells or how we can mimic
some of the attributes of these materials

in their capacity to
stimulate cellular behavior,

and we would really like to
use these particular materials
in areas such as cell culture,
in the preparation of both complex tissues
and tissue and disease models,
in the areas of regenerative medicine,
more specifically for cell delivery,
and in the area of drug delivery.
So I would really like to focus

on one particular area
that we're working on,
and that's in the development of
materials for 3D cell culture today.
So, if I was to ask this group of people
what they would like for lunch today,

this group of people would
say different things, surely.

Some would like pasta,
others would maybe like tacos
and some might like butter chicken,

but because we are in summer,
others might like barbecue.
But if this same group of people

were to be affected by
a particular disease,
most likely this same group of people
would be treated by a particular drug,
and most likely the same drug.
However, we now know that this model

doesn't necessarily
work, and that's because

of the genetic makeup of
the people in this group
is most likely, or is different,
and one area that looks forward to change
how we perform medicine, but also
in how we search for new drug candidates
and as well, how we understand disease

is the induced pluripotent
stem cell field.
And induced pluripotent stem cells

are essentially somatic
cells that can be taken
from a patient in a laboratory setting

and are reprogrammed into
their pluripotent state,

and then these cells can
be then differentiated
through using certain biochemical
and as well chemical factors

into the necessary cell types
such that one can perform

various, let's say, or
explore various applications
and disease modeling in drug screening
and as well, drug discovery, and as well

in toxicity testing of
various drug candidates.

But another area where
these cells can be used in
is in the area of cell therapy,

where, for example, one
can start to think of

repairing or regenerating
any tissue of interest.

So, although there has
been tremendous progress
in this field over the past 10 years,
or just over a decade since the groups
of Yamanaka and Thomson have discovered

these particular cells,
there are still problems
related to both their production
and as well as their application.

And in our research
group, we are interested
to see, or what we would like to do

is use a supramolecular
biomaterials approach
to overcome some of the challenges

in the production and
application of these cells,

and as well of their
differentiated derivatives.
So if we are to think about the natural,
if we're to think of a material
that should support these particular cells
we should think of the natural material
by which all cells reside in,

and that's the natural
extracellular matrix.

The extracellular matrix
is a complex composition

of both soluble and as
well, insoluble proteins

and it provides not only
the structural support

for these cells, but also
a water rich environment

with specific bioactive
cues to direct their growth,
and so one particular synthetic material
that has had great success in this regard
in mimicking this natural environment
is the hydrogel, and hydrogels

are composed of either
chemically cross-linked
or physically cross-linked polymers,
and these polymers can be outfitted
with various bioactive cues,

and in my research
group, we are interested

in using specifically
supramolecular hydrogels
because of their non-covalent character
which endows them with unique properties,
such as modularity, tunability,
responsiveness, dynamic character,

and when we outfit them
with bioactive cues,
potentially biomimetic character.
So in order to construct such polymers,
we need a monomer, and that monomer

should have some sort of
directional interactions

in order to propagate the
growth of these polymers,
and the particular directional interaction

that we're interested in
is in the hydrogen bond,
and for this, this is where it brought us
to the squaramide-moiety.
So, we use squaramides because

they are structurally
simple diatopic synthons,
and these can associate with one another

through hydrogen bonding at
both ends of the molecule,
or at both ends of the synthon,

and when we insert this
into the hydrophobic core
of a bolaamphiphilic monomer,

we can direct the growth
of polymeric structures
and these polymeric structures
can have lengths on the nanoscale.

These particular monomers,
although they form

really nano-objects, several
hundreds of nanometers

in length, they do not
form gel-phase materials.

So what we did was is we
took this squaramide unit

and then inserted this
into a tripodal monomer,
and also explored the hydrophilic,
and as well hydrophobic balance
in order to be able to construct
these types of fibrillar architectures.
So when we found the correct balance,

we were able to obtain
gel-phase materials,
and these gel-phase materials
are mechanically soft in character

similar to the properties
that are observed
in the embryonic environment,

but also they show
self-recovery properties.

So what we did is we took the
self-recovering character

of this particular
material and we pipetted it
with a single-cell suspension
of induced pluripotent stem cells,
and what we found is, is that
when mixing these two together,

we could easily see the
cells within this material,
but then also these cells showed

their expected behavior
after 24 hours in culture,
so they form very compact aggregates
which are typical for this cell type,
and then in a second step, what we did is
is because we wanted to see if
we could release the cells so that
we could perform downstream analysis,

and this was possible
with this particular gel
because of its supramolecular nature,

and this is just flow-activated
cell sorting experiment
where we show that the cells do retain
their pluripotent character,
and this is similar to the typical methods
by which these cells are expended on
in a 2D culture setup on vitronectin.
So, where to for these materials?
We've shown that they are cytocompatible,
we can easily see cells in them,
we can also release the cells,

and they do retain their
pluripotent character.
So if we think of the processes
of development, more specifically

in terms of cellular
development of a particular
cell subtype, or a particular cell type,

and also in the
self-organization of tissues,
what is very much necessary is that
there is this really concerted action
of both biochemical and biophysical cues
that are presented at both the right place
and the right time. And well,
so where does the leave our materials
and where do we need to go with them?
Well, the next steps, we have to see

how to modulate their
mechanical properties.
How stiff will we need to go?
Well that will depend on the target.
And what types of bioactive units

will we need in these
particular materials.
And once we have these bioactive units,
how dynamic will they need to be,

and as well, will they
need to be responsive?
So with this, I would like to thank
my research group over the years.
It's been a really fun experience

to work together, but
also I am extremely proud
of their accomplishments.

I would also like to
thank the larger group
with which my group is embedded in

which is the Supramolecular
and Biomaterials

Chemistry Group at the
University of Leiden,
and I would like to also thank
all my collaborators over the years,
the funding sources, as well as

I would to make a couple
of special mentions

to both my family for their
support over all of these years,

and as well being the very
first funders of my work,
and also I would like to especially thank
my husband, Pablo Englebienne.

He's been a long time
computational collaborator
in many projects, and as well for being

a collaborator at home.
And I would like to thank
all of you for your attention.
(audience applauding)
